author: Tierney Shaw | tierneyshaw@ku.edu
title: Do you have seasonal depression? Here's how to manage symptoms
text:
As daylight hours shorten and temperatures drop into the 40s and 50s, students may feel more than just a chill. For some, these environmental shifts bring an extra set of challenges — a battle with seasonal depression.
In winter months, it’s normal to crave warmer weather and feel more tired than usual, but if you begin to withdraw from activities, experience prolonged sadness or notice changes in your sleep and appetite, you may be dealing with seasonal depression.
"About 5% of Americans develop full-blown winter-onset depression each year, but the risk is considerably higher among today's college students," said University of Kansas psychology professor Dr. Stephen Ilardi.
What is seasonal depression?
According to the National Institute of Mental Health, seasonal depression, also known as Seasonal Affective Disorder, is “a type of depression characterized by a recurrent seasonal pattern, with symptoms lasting about 4−5 months out of the year.”
Dr. Ilardi said sunlight intake levels can also be a large contributor to seasonal depression.
"Reduced sunlight during the short, cloudy days of winter disrupts our body clocks and serotonin levels," Dr. Ilardi said.
A lack of sunlight can cause serotonin levels to drop, which can lead to feelings of sadness, lethargy and irritability. It can also disrupt the body's natural production of the sleep chemical melatonin, which affects sleep quality.
Signs of a problem
KU Counseling and Psychological Services (CAPS) clinician Stefany Ortiz said that students struggling with seasonal depression “may begin to isolate themselves from others, oversleep, skip classes and cancel plans.”
If you or someone you know is showing symptoms of seasonal depression, it may be beneficial to talk to a health care provider or a mental health professional.
Common signs include experiencing two weeks or more of:
Feelings of sadness or hopelessness.
Social withdrawal.
Low energy levels.
Changes in sleep pattern.
Slower speech and movement.
Changes in appetite.
Struggling to complete daily tasks.
Managing symptoms
Here are some ways that students can manage their seasonal depression and make it through the cold, winter months.
"The best self-help step is usually to start getting 30 minutes each day of exposure to outdoor sunlight — or to a therapeutic light box that can simulate sunlight," Dr. Ilardi said.
Light therapy is a common treatment for seasonal depression because it can promote serotonin production in the brain, and help regulate the body's circadian rhythm. Light therapy lamps should have an intensity of at least 10,000 lux for best results.
Sticking to a routine can also be helpful. "Be sure to engage in good self-care, setting aside enough time for: regular exercise, in-person social connections, nutritious meals and healthy sleep," Dr. Ilardi said.
Exercising releases endorphins and other feel-good chemicals in the brain, which can boost mood and energy. Similar chemicals are released when spending time with friends and loved ones. Isolation and inactivity can make depression symptoms worse.
Prioritizing nutritious meals and eight hours of sleep per night can stabilize the body’s energy levels and ensure good health. Not getting enough sleep can increase stress hormones such as cortisol, which can worsen depression symptoms and increase reactivity to negative emotions and stress.
Ask for support
If you’re struggling with seasonal depression symptoms, CAPS Access Clinician Stefany Ortiz said asking for help is encouraged.
“You’re not alone in your experience, and there are many resources and folks on campus who are ready to support you,” Ortiz said.
KU students have access to mental health resources through CAPS. CAPS offers drop-in appointments, individual therapy sessions, workshops and peer listening. Information on CAPS services can be found on its website. Students can also access further counseling through the Telus Student Support Program, which offers free, 24/7 counseling.
Counseling and Psychological Services is open from Monday through Friday from 8 a.m. to 5 p.m. Students can schedule an appointment through their website or by calling (785) 864-2277.

author: El Destape
title: ALERTA por calor: cómo sigue el clima en Santa Fe y en Rosario durante este viernes 3 de enero de 2025
text:
El viernes 3 de enero de 2025 se presentará con condiciones de nubosidad variable y calor intenso en las ciudades de [Santa Fe](https://www.eldestapeweb.com/tag/santa-fe) y en [Rosario](https://www.eldestapeweb.com/tag/rosario), según el informe del [Servicio Meteorológico Nacional](https://www.eldestapeweb.com/tag/pronostico-del-tiempo) (SMN). Las altas temperaturas serán protagonistas, mientras que el cielo alternará entre momentos despejados y algunas nubes pasajeras.
Ante el calor intenso, el SMN recomendó mantenerse hidratados, usar ropa ligera y de colores claros, y evitar la exposición prolongada al sol, especialmente durante las horas de mayor radiación, entre las 11 y las 16. También sugirió utilizar protector solar y gafas de sol para protegerse de los rayos UV.
Las autoridades recordaron la importancia de prestar especial atención a los grupos más vulnerables, como niños, personas mayores y quienes padecen enfermedades crónicas. En caso de presentar síntomas como mareos, fatiga o deshidratación, es necesario buscar asistencia médica de manera inmediata.
A pesar de la intensidad del calor, el clima del viernes será propicio para actividades al aire libre, siempre que se tomen las precauciones adecuadas. Los habitantes de Santa Fe y de Rosario podrán disfrutar de un inicio de fin de semana con buen tiempo, aunque será necesario estar atentos a las condiciones para evitar riesgos relacionados con las altas temperaturas.
Pronóstico en Santa Fe y en Rosario para este viernes 3 de enero de 2025
En la capital provincial, el día comenzará con una mínima de 22° y se espera que las temperaturas asciendan rápidamente hasta alcanzar una máxima de 35° durante la tarde. Las nubes serán intermitentes, aunque el sol prevalecerá durante gran parte de la jornada. No se anticipan precipitaciones, pero la humedad, típica de la región, aumentará la sensación térmica, acentuando la percepción de calor.
Rosario, por su parte, experimentará un clima similar. Las temperaturas oscilarán entre los 19° de mínima y los 33° de máxima. El cielo también mostrará nubosidad variable, pero con predominio de cielos mayormente despejados. Al igual que en Santa Fe, no se esperan lluvias, aunque las condiciones serán sofocantes debido a la humedad elevada.
¿Cuándo llueve en Santa Fe y en Rosario?
Según los pronósticos meteorológicos disponibles, no se esperan lluvias en Santa Fe ni en Rosario durante los próximos días. Las condiciones climáticas previstas indican cielos mayormente despejados y temperaturas elevadas, características típicas de la temporada estival en la región.
Es importante destacar que, aunque no se pronostican lluvias en el horizonte inmediato, las condiciones climáticas pueden cambiar. Por ello, se recomienda mantenerse informado a través de fuentes oficiales y actualizadas, como el Servicio Meteorológico Nacional.

author: Stefano De Marzo
title: London-based climate tech 44.01 nabs €33.9 million to eliminate CO2 by turning it into rock
text: Climate tech company 44.01 , a climate tech eliminating CO2 by turning it into rock using the natural power of mineralisation, announced the successful completion of a €33.9 ($37) million Series A funding round. Equinor Ventures led this round, with significant participation from Shorooq Partners in the UAE. Additional investors include (in alphabetical order): Air Liquide Venture Capital (ALIAD), Alumni Ventures, Amazon’s Climate Pledge Fund, Climate Investment, Innovation Development Oman, Planet A Ventures, Salica Oryx Fund, Siemens Financial Services, Sumitomo Corporation, and several others. Existing investors, including Breakthrough Energy Ventures, have also recommitted to supporting 44.01’s technology by participating in this round. 44.01 eliminates CO2 by turning it into rock. The company’s pioneering technology accelerates the natural process of CO2 mineralisation to remove captured CO2 permanently in less than twelve months. 44.01 takes CO2 captured directly from the air, or from hard-to-abate industrial processes, helping decarbonise vital industries and ultimately return the atmosphere to sustainable levels of CO2. The process is safe, scalable, and lasts forever. Talal Hasan, founder and CEO of 44.01, said: “We believe mineralization can play a significant role in protecting and repairing our climate. We are grateful to our investors for committing to that mission and demonstrating their confidence in our technology. In addition to providing finance, our investors bring a wealth of international expertise and experience that will help us to accelerate our development and ultimately mineralize CO2 at scale worldwide.” This substantial round of funding underscores the growing confidence in 44.01’s mineralization technology’s potential to eliminate CO2 safely, permanently, and at scale. The capital raised will allow 44.01 to further refine its technology, develop commercial-scale projects, and expand its deployment internationally. Mahmoud Adi, founding partner of Shorooq Partners, commented: “We are thrilled to make our first lead investment in climate tech with 44.01, a company at the forefront of innovative carbon sequestration solutions globally. The UAE has been vital in advancing climate tech initiatives, and its leadership is paving the way for them. We are proud to contribute to this mission. This investment aligns with our vision of fostering groundbreaking technologies that address critical global challenges and move towards a more sustainable and safer future.” Cindi Bough, managing director at Climate Investment, added: “We believe 44.01’s innovative carbon mineralization technology could contribute to efficient industrial decarbonisation worldwide. Climate Investment is well-placed to help commercialize and scale this technology through our unique partner network and significant CCUS experience, and we look forward to working closely with the 44.01 team.” 44.01 has completed successful pilot projects in Oman and the UAE. The company was awarded the prestigious Earthshot Prize in 2022 for the “Fix our Climate” category, and its Project Hajar in Oman was recently announced as an XPRIZE Carbon Removal Top 20 Finalist.

author: Pablo Rodríguez
title: El caos de Talgo y el bloqueo en el intercambiador dejan sin fecha la cuarta frecuencia con Madrid
text: Secciones Servicios Destacamos Edición Pablo Rodríguez Almería Jueves, 24 de octubre 2024 Necesitas ser suscriptor para acceder a esta funcionalidad. Opciones para compartir En marzo pasado, el ministro de Transportes, Óscar Puente, anunció el refuerzo del servicio entre Almería y Madrid con la incorporación de un nuevo tren. La propuesta tenía como objetivo resolver parte de los problemas ferroviarios de la provincia, cuyas conexiones con la capital del país son escasas y se ven sacudidas habitualmente por los retrasos en los viajes. El responsable gubernamental aseguró entonces que la medida, que dependía de varios factores para su ejecución, estaría en marcha en noviembre. Sin embargo, no será así. Tal y como ha podido confirmar IDEAL, la puesta en marcha no llegará a tiempo y se encuentra ahora mismo sin fecha. Dos son los motivos que han llevado a esta situación, según las fuentes consultadas por este periódico. El principal es el caos ocasionado por los nuevos trenes de Talgo. Los convoyes estaban llamados a fortalecer los servicios en el Norte de Renfe, que iba a trasladar parte de la maquinaria sustituida a otras conexiones, como la que enlaza Granada y Almería con Madrid. Los nuevos modelos, que empezaron a llegar en la primavera pasada, no han funcionado como se esperaba y, desde entonces, acumulan centenares de incidencias. El fabricante tampoco ha cumplido el calendario de entregas inicialmente previsto cuando se formalizó la compra. Los trenes empezaron a llegar en primavera pasada con tres años de retraso y en menor cantidad de lo esperado, informó el diario Público. Ambos factores han impedido que los trenes que tenían que reforzar el servicio quedasen liberados para su uso aquí, aunque no son la única causa de que la nueva frecuencia llegue a tiempo. La otra tiene que ver con el intercambiador de ancho de la línea Granada-Almería. Esta infraestructura, construida en el Cerrillo de Maracena, está pensada para permitir que el material móvil se adapte al tipo de vía que existe en la red entre ambas ciudades. La obra, que dependía del Administrador de Infraestructuras Ferroviarias -Adif-, quedó finalizada a comienzos del mes de junio pasado, cuando se realizaron las últimas pruebas para confirmar el buen estado de ejecución. Desde entonces, está bajo la responsabilidad de la Agencia Estatal de Seguridad Ferroviaria, órgano dependiente del Ministerio de Transportes que debe autorizar su uso. El visto bueno, sin embargo, todavía no ha llegado, lo que impide que Renfe pueda poner en marcha el nuevo servicio. Consultado por esta situación, el subdelegado del Gobierno en Granada, José Antonio Montilla, explicó ayer que es conocedor de las pruebas que se están haciendo en el intercambiador y aseguró que los trenes «están en camino». El dirigente no aclaró cuál es el nuevo horizonte temporal, pero afirmó que «si se produce un retraso será solo de unas semanas, pues se continúa trabajando para que ese tren Almería-Madrid, que será la cuarta frecuencia, empiece a funcionar lo antes posible». Así, las frecuencias de Granada y Almería continuarán por ahora como hasta el momento. La capital nazarí mantendrá los tres viajes diarios, mientras que la ciudad almeriense seguirá teniendo una única conexión con la capital de España. author: Sanjesh Singh
title: US men's rugby eliminated in Olympic quarterfinals, will not medal
text:
Team USA will not medal in men’s rugby in Paris .
The Eagles on Thursday fell to Australia 18-0 in their quarterfinal matchup , ending a chance to at least claim a bronze medal in the competition.
Australia will move onto the semifinals on Saturday, July 27, where it will play two-time gold medalists Fiji .
The Eagles, though, haven’t played their last game. They will play Ireland on Saturday at 9 a.m. ET in the first of two placement games.
2024 Paris Olympics Dec 13, 2023 2024 Paris Olympics: See dates, sports, how to watch and more 2024 Paris Olympics Dec 21, 2023 Here are the rules for the 2024 Olympics in Paris 2024 Paris Olympics Dec 20, 2023 Get to know Team USA Olympians ahead of the 2024 Paris Olympics They can finish the tournament as high as fifth place or as low as eighth place, depending on the result between New Zealand and Australia.
Fiji, Australia, South Africa and France are the four semifinalists, though one will not medal.
Team USA has not yet medaled in men’s rugby since it entered the Olympics in 2016.

author: Jose Carlos Diez
title: Palencia: Velilla suspende la Pinada del Mayo por la alerta de lluvias y tormentas | El Norte de Castilla
text: PalenciaVelilla suspende la Pinada del Mayo por la alerta de lluvias y tormentas Secciones Servicios Destacamos PalenciaVelilla suspende la Pinada del Mayo por la alerta de lluvias y tormentas Jose Carlos Diez Velilla Viernes, 10 de mayo 2024, 20:08 Necesitas ser suscriptor para acceder a esta funcionalidad. Compartir Velilla ha decidido suspender la tradicional Pinada del Mayo debido al aviso de nivel amarillo por lluvias y tormentas para este sábado emitido por la Agencia Estatal de Meteorología (AEMET) para la Cordillera Cantábrica. La actividad se iba a desarrollar desde las 10:00 horas, con la salida de los mozos de la plaza, hasta culminar por la tarde con la tradicional pinada y la merienda en la zona de la Reana. La decisión de suspender la Pinada del Mayo se ha tomado para preservar la seguridad de los participantes, ante las condiciones meteorológicas adversas pronosticadas. La cancelación de este evento, arraigado en la tradición local y recuperado hace años, ha generado cierta decepción entre los habitantes de Velilla, que esperaban con ilusión su celebración anual y ya vieron cómo la semana pasada se tuvo que aplazar. El alcalde, Gonzalo Pérez, ha comentado que la próxima semana «decidiremos qué hacemos y si la suspensión se convierte en definitiva». author: Caroline Catherman
title: Florida’s abortion destination status will be tested in 2024
text: In 2023, more than 7,000 women traveled to Florida to end their pregnancies. They came from hundreds of miles, originating from Texas, Georgia, Mississippi, even Central America and the Caribbean. This was the closest place they could legally get an abortion, given that the majority of the South banned the procedure after the U.S. Supreme Court ruled in June 2022 that abortion laws should be left up to the states. In total, one out of 10 of Florida’s 78,250 recorded abortions last year was done on an out-of-state resident, according to Florida Agency for Health Care Administration data released in early January. The number of total abortions shrank by about 4,000 compared with 2022 but out-of-state residents getting the procedure increased by over 400. As the Florida Supreme Court contemplates the constitutionality of the state’s currently active 15-week ban, a pending 6-week ban, and a proposed constitutional amendment to enshrine abortion access in the state’s constitution, these numbers are a reminder that the future of abortion in Florida could affect the entire Southeast. “A 6-week ban in Florida would definitely change the entire ecosystem of this work we do,” said Christine Montero, a coordinator for Access Reproductive Care-Southeast, which helps with funding and logistics for Southeast travel for women seeking abortions. The state Supreme Court is expected to issue a ruling, though it’s unknown when, that will determine whether Florida’s constitution currently allows for the state’s current 15-week limit and, by extension, the 6-week limit passed signed last year by Gov. Ron DeSantis that will only take effect if the 15-week ban is upheld. Both laws have limited exceptions for rape, incest, the mother’s life and fatal fetal abnormalities, though medical professionals have previously told the Orlando Sentinel that the law does not use clinical terms and is difficult to interpret. Six weeks of gestation is two weeks after a pregnant person misses their first period, and, combined with Florida’s current requirement of two in-person abortion clinic visits at least 24 hours apart, reproductive advocates and medical experts argue that a 6-week ban would amount to an all-out ban for many. Meanwhile, a proposed constitutional amendment that would protect abortion rights in Florida recently got enough signatures to qualify for the 2024 ballot, though anti-abortion advocates are challenging it. The Supreme Court must sign off on the language for the amendment to appear on the ballot in the fall. The court has set a Feb. 7 hearing to consider the wording. Advocates on both sides of the issue are watching with anticipation. “Florida’s a trendsetter,” said Orlando-area lawyer John Stemberger, a leading anti-abortion voice in the state. “… We need to do more to protect the unborn in Florida and create a culture of life that’s consistent with the region that we’re in.” There’s another side of the coin, too. Because Florida is an abortion destination, Floridians, faced with increased demand, dwindling staff and long wait times, aren’t always able to get appointments before the state’s 15-week cutoff and are increasingly traveling out of state as well. “In addition to increasing our capacity and appointment availability at our health centers, our compassionate and skilled patient navigators have helped Floridians who have needed abortion access after 15 weeks navigate out of their home state for care. If the 6-week abortion ban is implemented, their roles will become even more vital,” said Robyn Schickler, chief medical officer of Planned Parenthood of Southwest and Central Florida, in an emailed statement. The Brigid Alliance, a national network assisting people who need to travel for abortion, helped about 195 Florida women and girls to travel from Florida to get abortion care in 2023 to states that allow abortions later in pregnancy. The average total cost per person was about $3,000, and the average Floridian traveled over 1,800 miles round trip, said Serra Sippel, interim executive director. “People having to travel north to places where they can get the care, that is just so costly and [has] so many hurdles, especially [for] people in rural areas, people who have never left their states before, have never left their communities, have never been on a plane before,” Sippel said. Abortion funds say they are mostly able to meet demand but are still feeling the strain. In 2023, Access Reproductive Care-Southeast received a total of 32,398 calls to its health line and supported over 3,000 patients across the Southeast with abortion assistance totaling over $1.3 million. The network closed Wednesday for the rest of the month because it ran out of funds. “That’s not something that happens often but it is something that is happening. And it’s something that I foresee happening more because there is such high demand,” Montero said. In states with reduced abortion access, amid increasingly high OBGYN clinic wait times and funds stretched thin, other obstacles are popping up that make traveling for care more complicated and expensive. Some pregnant people will go to pregnancy clinics that offer free medical services like pregnancy tests, ultrasounds, and counseling. The centers lack regulatory oversight and have been reported to spread misinformation in an attempt to discourage abortion, according to The American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists. “They’re seemingly an accessible resource for folks to get information about pregnancy, but we have found that they cloud up people’s experiences, and maybe provide disinformation to get folks confused,” Montero said. Sipple and Montero said Brigid Alliance and Access Reproductive Care-Southeast have had multiple clients who received incorrect information from a crisis pregnancy center about how long they’ve been pregnant, traveled to another state, then realized they were farther along than the state allowed and were no longer within its limits, forcing them to travel again. “It’s just so disruptive and a horrible way to treat people. It’s just inhumane and so disrespectful,” Sippel said. Stemberger praised the pregnancy centers and the resources they provided. He called incidences of disinformation “isolated incidents, if at all.” “It’s ironic and rich that the abortion industry would be accusing these women of trying to do this,” he said. “These pregnancy centers are just trying to provide another option.” In addition to counseling against abortion, these centers offer classes on pregnancy and parenting, where they provide some pregnancy and baby supplies such as diapers or used baby clothes. The nonprofit Florida Pregnancy Care Network manages such clinics in Florida. The network secured a $29.4 million contract with the Florida Department of Health in October, according to records obtained by Reveal at The Center for Investigative Reporting. Ccatherman@orlandosentinel.com; @CECatherman Twitter

author: 网易
title: 葡体官方：昆达和埃苏戈将以总计7440万欧元加盟切尔西|转会费|葡萄牙|切尔西队|切尔西俱乐部_网易订阅
text:
官方消息，切尔西已经和葡萄牙体育就热奥瓦尼-昆达和达里奥- 埃苏戈 的转会达成协议。
葡萄牙体育官方公告
葡萄牙体育已经与切尔西就热奥瓦尼-昆达和达里奥-埃苏戈的最终转会达成全面协议，总价为74408816.32欧元，其中包括约6%的中介服务费用。
热奥瓦尼-昆达的转会费为52136541.32欧元，包括固定转会费分期付款50777700.00欧元和浮动奖金分期付款1358841.32欧元，浮动奖金取决于球员在2025/26赛季期间是否达到了与竞技表现相关的某些目标。
在2025/2026赛季期间，该球员将继续为葡萄牙体育效力，直至2025/2026赛季结束。
经双方同意，和第三方俱乐部团结机制相应的金额将由切尔西和葡萄牙体育平均承担。
中介服务费用为3550000.00欧元。
达里奥-埃苏戈的转会将在本赛季结束时进行，转会费为22272275.00欧元。
球员将继续在拉斯帕尔马斯效力，直至2024/2025赛季结束。
从2025/2026赛季开始，他将为切尔西俱乐部工作。
经双方同意，和第三方俱乐部团结机制相应的金额将由切尔西和葡萄牙体育平均承担。
中介服务费用为999687.00欧元。
